title.narrative: Promoting Access to Justice through Victim Participation

description.narrative: Victims have a central role in pushing forward innovative transitional justice approaches, and they should be empowered to influence and participate in the design and implementation of justice measures and policies. Without meaningful and diverse victim participation, policies dealing with the past are more likely to be detached from affected communities; face difficulties in generating local ownership; and fail to adequately address the grievances of victims. As part of Impunity Watch plan to equip victim groups and their supportive civil society organisations with knowledge and skills that would allow them to organise, campaign, and fully engage in justice effort; we started to provide partner organisations with advice and resources. Our objective is to enable them to work closely with survivors to raise their awareness on victims’ rights and transitional justice and the design and implementation of guarantees of non-recurrence

participating-org.narrative: Syrian Center for Media and Freedom of Expession

activity-date.narrative: Promoting Access to Justice through victim Participation

recipient-country.narrative: Objective is to favour the development of more comprehensive justice policies in Iraq through enhanced participation of victims, affected communities, and civil society actors in Nineveh

The objective is maintaining the momentum of post-TDC transitional justice efforts through robust participation of civil society organisations and victims’ representatives, particularly in criminal justice processes and the design and implementation of guarantees of non-recurrence

recipient-region.narrative: Project aims at advancing SDG16+ by ensuring meaningful participation of victims and affected communities in justice processes

Project aims at enabling victims of human rights abuses, as well as those supporting them, to advocate for their rights, including in the context of peace talks, recovery or relief initiatives, and possible reconstruction plans

policy-marker.narrative: The overall objective is to enhance justice and accountability processes and their impact on broader post-conflict efforts by strengthening the position of victims, and enabling their meaningful participation in the design and implementation of justice measures

description.narrative: First installment of the NL Ministry of Foreign Affairs according to the grant agreement

title.narrative: Promoting Access to Justice through Victim Participation
Promoting Access to Justice through Victim Participation

Recipient region 589: Output III.1.5 International policymakers, stakeholders and donors including international mechanism such as the IIIM and CoI receive through meetings, written advice and publications advice and information on issues such as victim participation in justice and peace processes, reconstruction and human rights and HLP matters in recipient region 589. International policymakers will additionally receive from SCM relevant up-to-date evidence-based material on international crimes and abuses in the recipient region 589

description.narrative: A separate MoU with IIIM was signed in April 2019, and significant progress has been made in this regards specifically in the context of SCM/VDC’s work on a case file against perpetrators from the non-state actor Islam Army. SCM Initiated a discussion with one Human Rights Clinic regarding a potential collaboration, and a partnership with Swisspeace has started in order to draft a global vision on what and how should Transitional Justice for Syria be like. To achieve this goal a first workshop has been organised and the second will happen in August 2019.

title.narrative: Through public statements, strategy discussions and other means CSOs and victims’ groups demonstrate increased knowledge in areas such as peacebuilding, documentation and memorialisation, victims’ rights and participation, TJ approaches, HLP, and business and human rights

description.narrative: SCM, worked on its report (Fighting Impunity on War Crimes committed against Journalists). The report was supposed to be launched on HRC 43rd session, but due to cancellation of this session, launching the report was postponed.

actual.value: 6 victim’s groups -with support from IW, PAX, and Women Now- and with sponsorship of DMFA, convened a side event in the run up to the Brussels IV conference in June, “Syrian Survivors Demand Justice, Accountability, and Meaningful Participation”. CFA participated in a public statement in Brussels IV. CFA, also participated in meetings with UN Syria Special Envoy, America Special Envoy and with number of meetings with local and International organisations. WSG participated in a campaign to support accountability effort towards GBV with a number of organisations. In addition, WSG participated in a meeting organised by EFI on challenges faced by women in HLP's right. ADMSP had a number of meetings with COI and IIIM to share information and response to certain requests and questions. Following the side event in the run of Brussels IV, Taáfi with collaboration from other victim’s groups reached out to policy makers and stakeholders, to stress out their demands and emphasis the need for victims' rights of participation in justice and peace process. Taáfi was able also to open a new channel of communication with Italy Syria Special Envoy. In addition, Taáfi also with collaboration with other victim’s groups had a meeting with UN Syria Special Envoy.

SLDP has finalized and submitted a contextual analysis related to SGBV in Syria to the IIIM. The final stages of this work incorporated reviewing the gathered material from SNGOs, holding 5 discussion meetings with women-led NGOs, and applying SLDP's learned lessons from its previous experience and engagement. SLDP has received a positive and welcoming feedback from the IIIM, and it further recommended contacts for Syrian lawyers specialized in the issue to be contacted by the IIIM. SLDP expects to develop this project with the IIIM into a more concrete steps in which SLDP seeks providing SNGOs with the needed and relevant support. Following the outbreak of the COVID pandemic, travel restrictions, lockdowns, and social distancing rules have prevented SLDP from being able to schedule and organize physical meetings in the timeframe 1st of April to 30th of June. SLDP used this time to advance its relationship with the targeted States in order to (1) increase their knowledge on Syria, (2) establish a more advanced level of understanding and interest in engaging in Syria (3) facilitate future engagement when physical meetings and travel related restrictions will be lifted. The Human Rights and Business Unit (HRBU) has provided international policymakers and stakeholders with various forms of advice regarding issues of business and human rights in Syria, particularly those relating to reconstruction and HLP rights issues. The HRBU participated in a meeting of a Syrian HLP legal experts network organized by GIZ to discuss HLP rights in Syria. During this meeting, SLDP briefed Syrian participants as well as GIZ on the role of businesses in violating HLP rights and identified methods through which such businesses could be held accountable.

title.narrative: Enhanced participation of CSOs and victims in the work of the IIIM and other official bodies are included in documents and statements released by such bodies or reflected in their practice and work

description.narrative: SLDP and IIIM couldn't re-meet to discuss and agree on the next steps of the SGBV analysis project due to the Covid19 outbreak. A meeting to develop this plan is scheduled for later.

actual.value: 5 victim groups and 12 CSOs participated in a meeting with IIIM and provided IIIM with a collaboration strategy.

title.narrative: Number of business and non-profit organisations involved in reconstruction efforts that demonstrate, publicly or privately, their concern for and commitment to respecting human rights principles in their work in recipient region 589

description.narrative: SLDP has met with regional humanitarian actors in Amman, Jordan, including governments and INGOs to discuss enhancing human rights due diligence for procurement activities in the Syrian context. SLDP has also met with the Commission of Inquiry on the Syrian Arab Republic to discuss the importance of focusing investigations on the role of businesses in human rights violations in Syria.

actual.value: IW and (SCM) on behalf of the Transitional Justice Coordination Group (TJCG), with the support of Dutch and Swiss MFAs organized a meeting in Leiden in January 2010 bringing together IIIM representatives and a group of civil society organizations and victims' groups ( ADMSP, Ta'afi and other victims' representatives) to discuss the different aspects and challenges related to the theme of unlawful attacks in Syria. The meeting served to enhance the work of IIIM and to deepen the trust and cooperation of Syrian organizations and the IIIM.

Ongoing technical support are provided to 6 victims' groups to actively and efficiently participate in justice endeavours and peace processes. - 4 victims' groups had a meeting in The Hague to develop a strategy aimed at reinforcing their participation in justice and accountability endeavours. During the meeting, IIIM and other international policy makers who were in attendance were advice to develop a strategic plan based on victim centred approach.

SLDP engaged with 10 international humanitarian organizations regarding their potential role in business related human rights violations in recipient region 589 and how they can strengthen their procurement and due diligence policies to ensure they are not financing human rights violators or war criminals

title.narrative: International policymakers, stakeholders and donors including international mechanism such as the IIIM and CoI receive through meetings, written advice and publications advice and information on issues such as victim participation in justice and peace processes, reconstruction and human rights and HLP matters in Syria

actual.value: SCM continued to provide counselling and support to CFA regarding its engagement with international mechanisms. The support included providing review, legal advice and translation. Documentation work on violations of IHL and HRL kept going through the reporting period. VDC published (12) infographics (on weekly basis) on violations related to the right of life of Syrians. VDC published (3) statistical reports (on monthly basis) on casualties in Syria. VDC published (3) infographics (on monthly basis) on violations related to the right of freedom of Syrians (detention, kidnapping, disappearance and release) The "Documentation of Violations

title.narrative: Recipient region 998 : Outcome 1.1 Policymakers involved in effort to advance SDG16+ including UN agencies and programmes (e.g. UNDP, UNWOMEN, OHCHR) and states members of the Task Force for Justice are willing to formulate more effective public policies to ensure victim participation, both formally and informally, in justice processes

description.narrative: Output I.1.1 Participatory research with partners result in publication(s) recommending models for victim participation in official and informal justice efforts

title.narrative: Statements and official documents published by policymakers and donors show that policies and measures to ensure enhanced victim participation in justice processes are considered in policy-making debates and processes at the international level

description.narrative: Objective: Advancing SDG16+ by ensuring meaningful participation of victims and affected communities in justice processes

actual.value: 3 Meetings of the Transitional Justice Working Group under the Task Force for Justice discussed victim participation in justice processes.

title.narrative: Statements of policies adopted at the national, regional or international level include language on victim participation and victim-centred justice

actual.value: Ongoing bilateral meetings with policymakers at the UN, the EU and at the national level demonstrate that victim participation and mechanisms to achieve it is becoming an item on the policy-making agenda.

The victim participation research in 5 countrries (Guatemala, Colombia, Tunisia, Indonesia and DRC) is being conducted by the research teams/partners on the grounds. Due to Covid restrictions, there we some delays but the first drafts from the country studies are expected in mid to late Q2. Based on the country studies, one general report which will include the findings and recommendations from the country studies will be developed. This report will be finalized in late Q2/early Q3

title.narrative: Recipient Region 998: Outcome I.2 Increased accountability of policymakers and governments on victim participation is made possible through the measuring of levels of participation and victims’ satisfaction

description.narrative: Output I.2.2 A set of practical indicators to measure effective victim participation and survivors’ satisfaction with justice processes

title.narrative: Material describing methodology and indicators is published, made available online and 100 copies is distributed to policymakers and civil society stakeholders

description.narrative: A lead researcher together with some of the local researchers have been identified and their ToR are being developed

title.narrative: Developed methodology and indicators for victim participation and satisfaction are considered by relevant government- or civil society actors- to measure progress towards access to justice and SDG16.3 in conflict and post-conflict settings

description.narrative: Research framework is being developed

title.narrative: Recipient region 998: Outcome I.3 Victim movements mobilise, organise themselves and participate effectively in global formal and informal efforts toward the fulfilment of 2030 SDG agenda

description.narrative: Output I.3.1 The capacity of 10 to 12 victims’ groups (from various world regions) to connect and create a global network is increased

title.narrative: 10 to 12 victim organisations representing Africa, the Americas, Asia, Europe and MENA initiate the formation of a functioning global victim network

description.narrative: 2 victim groups have developed a concept paper for the network and will soon convene first preparatory meeting in Q 4 which will include 8 to 10 victim organisations

title.narrative: An effective global network of victims is established and understands the potential to advance their rights and interests through the SDGs agenda

actual.value: Participants drawn from different part of the global participated in a meeting in January 2020 in The Hague to discuss next steps in network building and forming a core group of victims.
Preparation of a meeting with a core group of victim groups have started and is planned for January 2020 to discuss next steps in network building

title.narrative: Iraq: Outcome II. 1. Victims in Nineveh, with support from local CSOs operating in Nineveh and elsewhere in Iraq, are organised efficiently and strongly equipped to advocate for justice measures that are informed by their needs and experience

description.narrative: Output II.1.1: The capacity of 12 victim “leaders” and 4 to 6 CSOs in the area of transitional justice is expanded

title.narrative: 8 to 10 CSOs and victims’ groups demonstrate - in their programmes and publications - increased understanding of their rights, the nature of the crimes they experienced, the recourse that transitional justice approaches offer and of their potential as a political force that can influence justice policies

description.narrative: Means of Verification: Understanding among CSOs and victim grounds of their rights

actual.value: IW organised a miniseries of webinars for civic leaders active in documenting violations to take relevant lessons from transitional justice approaches from elsewhere in the region featuring experts from Syria, Tunisia, Gaza and Bahrain. IW also spoke at an online event for Iraqi youth activists giving comparative perspectives on accountability in other contexts of repression against demonstrators.

title.narrative: Iraq: Outcome II.2 Civil society groups, victims’ representatives and affected communities in Nineveh increasingly participate in formal and informal efforts aimed at improving current justice measures or designing new ones

description.narrative: Output II.2.1: A functioning civil society platform is created and its capacity is developed through training/workshops

title.narrative: A functioning platform of 6 to 8 CSO is established to facilitate their participation in justice efforts

description.narrative: Contextual challenges in Iraq (political instability, US-Iran tensions, ongoing protests and the coronavirus pandemic) continued to make the timing for the launch of a civil society platform poor.

actual.value: 11 Iraqi NGOs working collectively in an informal working group were advised and supported to engage with UNITAD and further their collective action. Project partners targeted Iraqi policymakers in a series of web events (under a separate project) promoting enhanced means to address SGBV in Iraq and greater recognition of structural root causes behind its persistence, as well as via a joint policy brief and advocacy statements.

A working group of Iraqi NGOs from across the ethno-sectarian spectrum continued their cooperation, submitting a draft protocol of cooperation developed in 2020 to UNITAD, followed by a joint letter to the UN Secretary General providing input regarding the appointment of a new Special Adviser to UNITAD, which was also targeted with written policy advice on victim participation by IW with input from its Iraqi partners.
Assistance was provided to Iraqi NGOs to draft a joint call for a special session on Iraq at the human rights council, which unfortunately was cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic.

Local, national and international policymakers were targeted by the media briefing described above. Written and oral advice was provided to UNITAD, international government representatives, and civil society groups regarding civil society and victim participation in accountability efforts for ISIS perpetrators. Collective negotiations and discussions were facilitated with 11 Iraqi civil society groups acting in victims’ interests on joint advocacy positions. However, plans for a formal platform remain on hold in light of civil society’s preoccupation with the tense political and economic situation in the country, as well as reverberations from the coronavirus pandemic.

title.narrative: Partner organisations draft policy proposals and statements that are practical and that favour participatory and inclusive justice processes

description.narrative: Continued unrest and political volatility in Iraq in Q4 distracted national policymakers from justice issues and prevented further progress on the civil society platform, although coordination with the potential members continued.

title.narrative: A functioning platform of 6 to 8 CSO is established to facilitate their participation in justice efforts

description.narrative: During a visit to Iraq, IW deepened its existing relations with CSOs active in the field of transitional justice and met new potential partners, as well as holding preliminary discussions on the CSO platform. A two-day meeting was held for Iraqi civil society and policymakers to outline the challenges in terms of victims’ rights and to develop join actions and positions.

title.narrative: At least 4 to 6 CSOs engage in official and informal processes in Northern Iraq aimed at improving current justice and redress measures or designing new ones

Iraq: Outcome II.3 Iraqi and international policymakers have a better understanding of victims’ needs and demands and consequently consider policies to and provide them with redress and contribute to address Nineveh’s multi-layered legacy of abuses and grievances

description.narrative: Output II.3.1:Research is produced on victims’ needs and demands and findings disseminated to policymakers

title.narrative: Policy discussions on justice, reflected in closed-door meetings, public statements, and actions, include transitional justice language

description.narrative: Work commenced on a review of transitional justice measures in Iraq, 2003-2020

title.narrative: Policymaking processes, reflected in public statements, policy documents and media coverage, examine the root causes of abuses and conflict and reflect a better understanding of victims’ needs and grievances

actual.value: A policy brief was developed with input from civil society partners on the topic of post-ISIS justice and victims’ rights in Iraq and Syria and distributed to international policymakers.

comment.narrative: National policymakers were preoccupied with domestic political instability and less approachable for advocacy efforts.

actual.value: A research project was initiated on the role of violent or hegemonic masculinities in maintaining Iraq’s culture of impunity and victimising both men and women, expected to be published in 2021. Work also began on another piece of research mapping Iraq’s various transitional justice-related initiatives since 2003, and the extent to which they meet victims’ needs for truth, justice and redress. Planning took place for a series of closed webinars (scheduled for July 2020) for Iraqi activists sharing lessons from expert resource persons from Gaza, Syria, Tunisia and Bahrain on accountability efforts after wide-scale violations against protestors to help them refine their advocacy demands and documentation methodology. After receiving written and oral advice from IW, UNITAD held two online briefings for Iraqi and international civil society to explore improved cooperation mechanisms. Written and oral advice was also provided in this regard to relevant Iraqi civil society organisations representing or working directly with victims of the ISIS occupation and conflict.

Work continued on a report on masculinity and its role in the militarisation of Iraqi society and ensuing cycles of victimisation. Research was also commissioned on spurious court cases against Iraqi activists and means to address them. UNITAD continued to engage with Iraqi civil society supported by IW via its dialogue forum. IW exchanged with 4 international NGOs on shared advocacy initiatives and advice on transitional justice in Iraq.

title.narrative: Recipient region 589; Outcome III.2 Efforts for truth, accountability, justice and redress are reinforced by effective use of reliable documentation work

description.narrative: Output III. 2.1 Documentation is produced through collecting, verifying and analysing data on violations and publishing reports

title.narrative: Documentation is produced through collecting, verifying and analysing data on violations and publishing reports.

description.narrative: Evidence based monthly reports were published, along with the yearly report for 2019. Six special reports were published (do not forget detainees, bloody cost-mass graves in Raqqa, Syrian refugees in Lebanon between arbitrary arrest and an unfair judiciary, Syrian refugees in neighbouring countries-violated rights and possible risks, attacks on Idleb Jan 2020, attack on Sarmin city, attacks on Marrat Alnoman). Additionally, VDC published 7 Press releases (World health day, the right to truth day, refugees at the Greek boarders, attack on Daraa, releasing students in Damascus, release Syrian detainees in Cyprus, fears of a COVID-19 pandemic in Syrian detention centres).

actual.value: Documentation work on violations of IHL and HRL kept going through the reporting period. Five special reports were published (Landmines in Daraa - THE DAY OF REMEMBRANCE FOR ALL VICTIMS OF CHEMICAL WARFARE - Northwest Syria Under Military Operations - COVID-19 IMPLICATIONS ON THE ECONOMIC SITUATION OF SYRIAN REFUGEES IN NEIGHBORING COUNTRIES OF SYRIA VDC published monthly infographics on violations related to the right of freedom of Syrians (detention, kidnapping, disappearance and release) VDC has published two videos; one on the Al-Houta Hole and the other on the International Day in Support of Victims of Torture VDC participated in a joint NGO report namely "Into the unknown: listening to Syria’s displaced in the search for durable solutions" by conducting several interviews and questionnaires with Syrian IDPs and refugees SCM supported the efforts of Caesar Families Association in collecting, verifying and analysing information of relatives of victims of torture and enforced disappearance

Evidence based monthly reports were published, along with other 3 special reports on Peace Spring operation, the attacks on Idlib and Hama, Attack on Qah. Additionally, 3 reports were drafted to be published in Jan 2020.

SCM published the following: (12) weekly infographics on violations related to the right of life of Syrians; (3) monthly statistical reports on casualties in Syri; (3) monthly infographics on violations related to the right of freedom of Syrians (detention, kidnapping, disappearance and release); (13) weekly posts on the rights of Syrian refugees; an annual Statistical Report on human rights violations in Syria; a statement on the International Day for the Right to the Truth; a report on torture in Syria named "Invisible Scars: Torture and its Legal and Socio-Economic Implications".
VDC published 2 Press releases; Beside weekly info-graphics on violations related to the right of life of Syrians.

title.narrative: Material produced by international stakeholders and policymakers involved in justice efforts refer to documentation and material produced by SCM

description.narrative: SCM/VDC continued its data collection and documentation activities as planned. Evidential material on violations by all parties all over the country was collected. Evidence-based monthly reports were published, including summary report on the recent military attacks on Idlib and Hama in March 2019. To support advocacy efforts, SCM/VDC also published a summary statement on the recent offensive on Idlib and Hama in May 2019, as well as an info-graphic to document the casualties over the entire offensive in the North

title.narrative: Documentation is produced through collecting, verifying and analysing data on violations and publishing reports

actual.value: The team also expanded its work to include monitoring the violations against refugees in Greece and the Balkans, in addition to monitoring the change in the policies of European countries (Denmark, for example) towards Syrians under the pretext that Damascus, Aleppo and some other areas in Syria are safe. The team prepared a statement on the matter in cooperation with ACHR as members of the VDSF The "UN Mechanisms" team in collaboration with the "Journalists' House" project team has prepared a public submission on the media environment in Syria 2019, which targets: the Special Rapporteur on the promotion and protection of the right to freedom of opinion and expression, the Special Rapporteur on the situation of human rights defenders; Working Group on Arbitrary Detention; Working Group on Enforced or Involuntary Disappearances; Special Rapporteur on extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions; Special Rapporteur on torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment Additionally, the "UN mechanisms" team prepared and sent (5) individual complaints on alleged enforced or involuntary disappearances to be submitted to the Working Group on Enforced or Involuntary Disappearances A semi-annual report on detainees (second-half of 2020) named "Don't Forget the Detainees" was published. A report named "Deep Scars" on the violations committed against children was also published

title.narrative: Recipient region 589: Outcome III.4 The Syrian Negotiations Commission (SNC) is prepared and ready to negotiate justice and redress matters (IW)

description.narrative: Output III. 4.1 Syrian Negotiation Committee (SNC) and other key players in political processes including the Office of the Special Envoy for Syria receives ongoing technical support and strategic advice, including through meetings, policy papers, briefings and other forms of outreach

title.narrative: Members of the SNC show increased knowledge and understanding of transitional justice through the development of strategies to include transitional justice in SNC negotiations

description.narrative: SCM advocacy efforts in the first quota of 2020 were affected by the Corona pandemic, and restricted to online activities, especially with the cancellation of HRC sessions, and delay of donors’ conference in Brussels. SCM also responded to the pandemic, and developed a quick response plan to cover the politicization of the health crisis, in Syria and beyond. Several activities were planned around 43rd session of HRC, including 2 side events, advocacy sessions for a group of civil society actors. unfortunately, the plans had to be suspended. Additionally, SCM, alongside with a group of Syrian CSOs, participated in a meeting with US special Envoy to Syria to discuss US policy in the region, especially on accountability, and justice, sanctions, and funding plans. SCM also Developed, shared and published a statement on health conditions in Syrian Detention Centers- Covid-19.

actual.value: 12 members of the SNC with constitutional members participated in a meeting to discuss a strategy to include transitional justice in SNC negotiations
SCM (through VDC project) supported CFA documentation staff in collecting, analysing, and documenting information gathered from families who have identified their family members in Caesar photos.

SCM issued a position paper, and a legal analysis on the Lebanese government’s policy on refugees. The joint position paper was signed by 42 organizations, and was shared with the UN secretary general and the UNHCR.

title.narrative: Recipient region 589: Outcome III.1 Justice CSOs and victims’ associations in recipient region 589 increase their ability and resources to participate in ongoing justice processes and initiatives (IIIM, CoI, UJ criminal litigation, etc.), advocate for victims’ rights, and influence the work of decision/policy-makers, businesses and humanitarian actors

description.narrative: Output III.1.1 Policy, technical and legal support is provided to both civil society and victims’ groups, through workshops, toolkit and hands-on coaching. Topics of capacity building activities may be in areas of transitional justice, UN Human Rights Mechanisms, business and human rights law as well as wider relevant areas of international law

title.narrative: Through public statements, strategy discussions and other means CSOs and victims’ groups demonstrate increased knowledge in areas such as peacebuilding, documentation and memorisation, victims’ rights and participation, TJ approaches, HLP, and business and human rights

description.narrative: Objective: Enabling victims of human rights abuses in recipient region 589, as well as those supporting them, to advocate for their rights, including in the context of peace talks, recovery or relief initiatives, and possible reconstruction plans

actual.value: 15 SNGOs received +22 training from SLDP
IW signed contracts with 2 sub-grantees

title.narrative: Number of Syrian CSOs and victims’ groups playing an active role in meetings related to international peacebuilding, reconstruction/relief/early recovery and justice debates concerning Syria

description.narrative: SLDP provided 32-hour information sessions to 4 victims and survivors groups addressing different aspects of IHL, ICL and IHRL in the context of reviewing and amending their coalition Charter. SLDP has also provided a 3-day training for a group of 18 women in the context of a leadership programme. The training addressed international law and advocacy with special focus on women and gender issues. SLDP is currently preparing information documents on transitional justice - particularly reparations - in response to a request by the coalition of the victims’ groups. The documents are intended to improve the groups knowledge and understanding in this area, and assist them in developing their own approach toward transitional justice in Syria. SLDP has also completed an explanatory report in Arabic for Syrian civil society which explains the current sanctions framework on Syria in the US, EU, and the United Nations. An English version of the report will be published soon.

actual.value: From Impunity Watch's sub grant and technical support, the victims/ survivors associations accomplished the following outputs: -Urnammu documented 45 new cases of detention and updated or modified 51 other cases. Urnammu started working in two thematic reports based on its documentation project.’ Urnammu started working on psychosocial support program where it hired therapist and developed the basic materials. Women Survivors Group (WSG) started working on their book project which will contain testimonies of former female detainees. WSG launched a campaign titled “the Other Prison “to combat the stigma the female detainees face when they are released. Also, WSG with partnership with Dawlaty contributed to policy brief about Women Human rights in Syria. In addition, WSG expanded its partnership and signed MOU with Syrian Women Network. Caesar Families Association (CFA) continued building the capacity of its member, hiring new staff and expanded the number of its members. CFA continued raising awareness about detention and enforced disappearance and victims’ rights, this included publishing articles in a number of media outlets and attending an online training on storytelling conducted by Syria Campaign. In addition, CFA with partnership of SCM filled two complaints to WGEID and attended a number of advocacy meetings with stakeholders and policy makers such as IIIM and Ireland foreign Minister. Also, CFA continued its documentation efforts with support of VDC/ SCM. Association of Disappeared and the Missing of Sednaya Prison (ADMSP) documented 162 enforced disappearance cases and 16 cases of former detainees into two databases. ADMSP expanded its documentation efforts to former detainees from other prisons in addition to those from Sednaya prison. Moreover, ADMSP published its report on enforced disappearance and financial extortion that families of victims suffered. ADMSP also supported survivors and their families to reach to different services such as legal, health and psychosocial support. Finally, ADMSP participated in number of meetings with stakeholders such as, IIIM, COI, ICRC and ICMP. Ta’afi supported 15 survivors of detention with housing, physical and mental health support, legal advice, training and job opportunities. Ta’afi participated in number of advocacy meetings with states representatives, policy makers and stockholders including advocacy meetings related to 46 session of HR council. Moreover, Ta’afi with collaboration of Crisis Action convened a diplomatic meeting hosted by the Sweden embassy in Beirut to advocate for the Charter’s demands and priorities. - Five victims’ associations (Ta’afi, ADMSP, Massar, CFA, and Families for Freedom) with collaboration of Cairo centre for HR convened a side event on the margin of HR council.
SCM published on its digitals, a series of recommendation targeting civil society actors, human rights defenders, citizen journalists, on their cyber security

title.narrative: Recipient region 589: Outcome III.3 Issues of justice, accountability, and redress are taken into account by those involved in the peace process and activities pertaining to relief and reconstruction

description.narrative: Output III.3.1 International policymakers are targeted by advocacy efforts aimed at ensuring that Issues of justice, accountability, and redress are taken into account by those involved in the peace process and activities pertaining to relief and reconstruction

title.narrative: International policymakers are targeted by advocacy efforts aimed at ensuring that Issues of justice, accountability, and redress are taken into account by those involved in the peace process and activities pertaining to relief and reconstruction

description.narrative: SLDP organized a meeting between 3 victims’ groups and representatives of Peru and Uruguay in January 2020 in Geneva. The meeting was as a result of an initiative from SLDP to engage with non-engaged states. The meeting resulted in an appreciation by the states and openness to explore further means of engagement such as organizing a thematic side event in Geneva on enforced disappearance with the participation of these victims’ groups. SLDP is maintaining its relationship with these states and others such as Argentina and Chile and is providing them with regular updates on the SNGOs and victims groups activities and plans. However, due to the Covid19 outbreak, physical and other in person activities had to be postponed. In the context of this focus, SLDP is facilitating an exchange of experience between Argentina NGOs and Syrian victims’ groups. This resulted from SLDP's contact and engagement with these Argentine groups to explore potential collaboration in supporting the Syrian victims’ groups narratives, demands and advocacy approaches with the non-engaged states. SLDP has also met with a number of policymakers regarding the use of sanctions as an interim method of accountability, and an alternative form of accountability for those involved in business related human rights violations, including those tied to relief or reconstruction.

actual.value: A meeting with the Syrian High Negotiations Committee was made to push for inclusive transitional justice in the future Syrian Constitution.

SCM attended the 40th FIDH’s Congress in Taipei, Taiwan; SCM's CEO met with ICC Chief prosecutor and held a meeting with her to discuss two main points: the complaint made by Guernica 37 and sustained by 63 Syrian organisations about Syrian forced migration to Jordan and its consequences on receiving states.

SLDP has got in touch with policymakers and representatives of participating EU countries at the Brussels Conference V targeted toward international around issues of reconstruction and business related human rights violations in Syria, and sanctions. This includes engagement with German, French, Swiss, EU, UK and Dutch policymakers to highlight the need to put conditions to humanitarian agencies funding in Syria to observe a level of human rights due diligence.

title.narrative: Syrian CSOs and victims’ organisations engaged in justice and accountability work develop strategies and resources to influence peace building processes and reconstruction discussions

Tunisia: Outcome IV.3 Mutual reinforcement of victims’ capacity in the MENA region and solidarity between them is enabled through the creation of a regional platform of survivors of serious human rights violation

description.narrative: Output IV. 3.1: Regional cross-learning on victim participation in transitional justice processes through exchange meetings (based on the Tunisian experiences among others)

title.narrative: Number of CSA in Iraqi, in recipient region 589 and in MENA who develop concrete new advocacy strategies inspired by Tunisia’s experience as shown in their activities and publications

target.value: number of cso's who develop concrete advocacy strategies

title.narrative: Number of female survivors who organise and voice their demands in recipient region 589, Iraq and other participating countries as shown through their activities

Tunisia: Outcome IV.1 Tunisian CSOs and victims’ groups are better equipped to actively participate in and influence the post-TDC transitional justice process, in particular through their engagement in advancing guarantees of non-repetition, gender justice and memorisation

description.narrative: Project Objective: Maintaining the momentum of post-TDC transitional justice efforts through robust participation of civil society organisations and victims’ representatives, particularly in criminal justice processes and the design and implementation of guarantees of non-recurrence

title.narrative: Victims groups and CSOs can articulate a strong understanding of institutional reform processes and conceive proposals for guarantees of non-recurrence as demonstrated in their work and publications

description.narrative: Means of Verification: Production and publication of final research and analysis

actual.value: 5 meetings with CSOs and victims

title.narrative: Recipient Region 589: Output III.1.3 Survivor associations' knowledge of their rights and capacity to organise and actively participate in justice endeavours and peace processes is developed through training activities

description.narrative: SLDP provided 2 training - including one Training of Trainers - for members of 12 victim’s groups and NGOs. In total 18 participants benefited from these training and a customised material was developed for the interested groups and NGOs to ensure delivering the training to the rest of the organisations' team members.

title.narrative: Syrian CSOs and victims’ organisations engaged in justice and accountability work develop strategies and resources to influence peace building processes and reconstruction discussions

description.narrative: Based on IW's support, survivors' associations accomplished the following outputs: - CFA participated in training on advocacy and communication in collaboration with SCM. CFA also conducted a meeting with other 6 victims’ groups to enhance collaboration among them and exchange experiences. In addition, CFA launched its website. - Women survivors groups keep working on internal organisational development and their visual identity. ADMSP documented 30 cases of violations of detainees’ rights and 48 enforced disappearance cases in two databases. ADMSP opened channel of communication between 3 survivors and COI - Ta'afi supported 14 survivors of detention with housing, physical and mental health support, legal advice, training and job opportunities. Ta'afi also created a channel of communication between media and research institutions (like CVT institution and Washington Post).

actual.value: Based on IW's sub grant and other technical support, the victims/ survivors associations accomplished the following outputs: Caesar Family Association participated in trainings on online advocacy campaign and acquired knowledge on how to engage with UN mechanisms and special procedures. CFA increased its outreach among the local and international stockholders, through publishing promotional video about the association' goals and objectives, and through written and video interviews with the associations' members. CFA in collaboration with VDC, documented and reached out to 300 relatives of victims’ families. CFA conducted an online advocacy campaign, which targeted 30 local organisation and association to raise awareness about victims of torture. Women survivors Groups finalised its founding documents and launched its website. In addition, WSG reached out to 136-woman survivor to introduce the group's goals and objectives. WSG widened its network and partnerships with local organisations, where the groups' members could participate in number of advocacy and legal trainings and participate in advocacy campaign on GBV. ADMSP documented 32 cases of violations of detainees’ rights and 102 enforced disappearance cases in two databases. ADMSP launched a new project to provide health and psychological support to the victims of torture in cooperation with CVT. Ta'afi supported 11 survivors of detention with housing, physical and mental health, legal advice, training and job opportunities. Taáfi helped documentation organisations to reach out to new survivors. In addition, Taáfi worked on engaging Solidarity Network members in advocacy work. Taáfi also participated in training on engaging with UN mechanisms.

SCM conducted 2 online workshops to support victims of chemical weapons in the establishment process of their organization. SCM conducted 2 online training sessions to CFA members (families of victims) on online team work and communication to enhance their capacity in organizing events and work together in order to engage with decision makers, international and local authorities.
SCM conducted 3 online workshops to raise awareness of 10 victims of chemical weapons.

SCM provided technical support to CFA in organizing a virtual event for the International Day for the Support of Victims of Torture. SCM provided CFA with several online training sessions on advocacy and provided consultation to CFA members in communicating with media and public speaking. SCM provided hands on coaching to 2 CFA members during the preparation and coordination of the event to ensure they have increased their capacity in organising online events.

title.narrative: Number of Syrian CSOs and victims’ groups playing an active role in meetings related to international peace-building, reconstruction/relief/early recovery and justice debates concerning Syria

description.narrative: SCM provided one victim organisation with an advocacy basic training in addition to other remote sessions on secure communication. 5 victim groups participated in Brussels III conference ( meetings with policy makers) to influence their work in peace process. SCM supported 7 victim's associations in their communication with ICRC by organizing a workshop for these associations to allow their active participation in future peace and transitional justice processes. SCM worked on a legal analysis for the Amnesty which was issued by the head of the Syrian regime Basshar Alassad on March 22nd, and it was circulated widely with policy makers, and also on SCM digitals.

actual.value: 5 victim groups participated in Brussels 3 conference. 2 training - including one Training of Trainers - for members of 12 victim’s groups and NGOs

title.narrative: Number of activities led by CSOs and victims’ groups from recipient region 589 playing an active role advocating and presenting their case and demands in meetings related to international peace building, reconstruction/relief/early recovery and justice debates concerning the region

description.narrative: SLDP provided a 3-day training for a group of displaced women -addressing forced displacement and the relevant legal redresses. SLDP tailored the training to enable this newly created group to utilize the legal knowledge in their planning, advocacy and outreach. The second stage of this capacity building project is ongoing and it will consist of remote follow-up and further provision of information and practical exercises to enable the group members to integrate their knowledge in statements, speeches, and other advocacy tools. The project entails also the selection of a smaller group to be further capacitated to lead the main group's activities and representation.

actual.value: VDC supported the participation of 4 victims' groups in a side event in Geneva in September. Victims' groups were able to communicate with IIM, COI, ICRC, UN Mechanisms and other stakeholders -including donors- to sensitise them about the role of victims in accountability and justice.

title.narrative: Iraq: Output II.1.1.The capacity of 12 victim “leaders” and 4 to 6 CSOs in the area of transitional justice is expanded

8 to 10 CSOs and victims’ groups demonstrate - in their programmes and publications - increased understanding of their rights, the nature of the crimes they experienced, the recourse that transitional justice approaches offer and of their potential as a political force that can influence justice policies.

description.narrative: A workshop for 18 Iraqi activists and CSO representatives to strategise on advocacy for justice goals and learn techncial skills in documenting human rights violations and writing reports was planned, but unfortunately had to be indefinitely postponed at the last minute due to the Coronavirus pandemic

actual.value: IW helped secure funding for the protection of human rights defenders at risk of assassination due to their opposition activities and advised on the implementation of this work, which will be further enhanced in 2021. A new partnership with a youth group closely aligned with the protest movement was initiated, aiming to support its research and advocacy capacities in favour of accountability and redress for violations against protestors and human rights defenders. In light of ongoing restrictions on travel to Iraq, a local consultant was hired to improve outreach to victim leaders who are hard to reach via online means.

New partnerships were explored and initiated with three victim groups, a feminist organisation, and a youth group. They received training and mentorship on proposal writing, financial management, and victims’ rights. Six victim activists threatened for their human rights work received temporary relocation and protection support, allowing them to continue their activism in the medium term. Diplomats and international civil society were targeted via an online briefing co-facilitated by two Iraqi partner organisations and IW on the need for accountability after violations against youth protestors. This led to follow-up bilateral meetings, also drawing on the recommendations from our 2020 policy brief, with the French and Dutch embassies in Baghdad as well as UNAMI.

Six grassroots activists in the Iraqi protest movement (many of whom had been subject to threats, malicious court cases and other forms of victimisation designed to curtail their activism), were supported to refine their messaging and demands before addressing journalists, civil society and Iraqi and international policymakers at an online media briefing on the protest movement. Material sharing lessons learned from Syrian civil society organisations’ experiences with the IIIM was developed and shared with Iraqi civil society groups. A training and exchange workshop in Erbil for Iraqi documentation activists was postponed indefinitely due to the coronavirus pandemic. Parts of the content were adapted into an online format for delivery in July 2020 as an interim activity until a physical workshop can be rearranged.

title.narrative: Iraq: Output ll. 3.2 International policymakers and donors are targeted by advocacy efforts of our Iraqi partner organisations calling for comprehensive redress measures for victims

Policymaking processes, reflected in public statements, policy documents and media coverage, examine the root causes of abuses and conflict and reflect a better understanding of victims’ needs and grievances

description.narrative: Human Rights Council members were targeted by the advocacy efforts of our partners.

actual.value: A side event at the ICC’s annual conference, a public event, a parliamentary visit, advocacy meetings, media appearances, and a conference all gave opportunities for victims and civil society groups to articulate their needs and demands. These events also provided opportunity to reach policymakers through written advice contained in a policy brief on accountability for ISIS. A research and networking visit to Erbil in November 2019 allowed IW to meet new potential partners, including victims’ groups, and to understand their needs and aspirations.

title.narrative: Tunisia: Output IV.1.3 CSOs and victims’ groups receive ongoing technical and strategic advice in their efforts to monitor and engage with officials involved in the implementation of TDC recommendations
Number of victims’ groups consulted by officials and participating through their representatives in public debate around the implementation of TDC recommendations.

description.narrative: IW met with director of National Archives to facilitate cooperation with victim groups on memorisation

actual.value: IW met with director of National Archives to facilitate cooperation with victim groups on memorisation.

title.narrative: Number of legislative or policy reform proposals submitted by CSOs and victims’ organisations

description.narrative: IW worked with a victim group Karama Association to develop a project to draft a bill for the creation of a memory institution. Concept was developed, and agreement was made with expert.

title.narrative: Recipient Region 998: Output I. 3.1 The capacity of 10 to 12 victims’ groups (from various world regions) to connect and create a global network is increased
8 to 10 victims’ groups from around the globe, formally or informally, participate in international gatherings and events related to 2030 agenda and access to justice

description.narrative: IW organized the first core group meeting for 3 days in The Hague in late January for representatives of 8 different victims’ group. Throughout the three days of the meeting, discussions focused on the establishment of the Network. Group members identified the following topics for the Network to focus on: how to tackle prolonged impunity; how to address the gap between promised reparations and their implementation in practice; how to move from top-down and expert-led transitional justice processes to meaningfully involving survivors; how to engage in dialogue with governments to advocate for bottom-up policies and build bridges between governments and victims and survivors; how to create more space for and (re)empower grassroots movements; how to advance discourse on solidarity with and amongst survivors; how to share experiences with younger generations and students and communicate brutal and violent stories in a way that they can be heard by the broader public; how to tackle the de-humanisation of victims; the need to ensure the sustainability and cross-cutting membership in the Network and not only speak to like-minded organisations; and the need for political and material support. The Core group members are currently working on developing and drafting the foundation documents of the Network which will be ready in Q2 and will form the basis for expanding and launching the Network.

actual.value: IW has been working closely with the Core Group Members of the Network to draft and finalize the founding documents of the Network which will help in the launching of the Network and increasing its membership base. These documents include the Founding Charter, the Statutes and the Ethical Charter of the Network. They will be finalized in Q3. The Core Group members came up with a name for the Network: INOVAS (International Network of Victims' and Survivors' of Serious Human Rights Abuses).

title.narrative: Tunisia: Outcome IV.2 Victims’ access to justice through complaints to the Specialised Chambers (SC) or other jurisdictions and mechanisms is protected and further reinforced
Victims’ understand available judicial avenues to advance their right to justice as demonstrated in their work, public statements, pleadings or judicial complains

description.narrative: Means of Verification: Victims' feedback

actual.value: Working group with four experts set up to develop a reform matrix.

title.narrative: Iraq: Output II.3.3 National policymakers examine with local stakeholders and international resource persons how victims’ rights are currently being dealt with and explore alternative approaches drawn from comparative transitional justice experiences in closed-door meetings and workshops

Policymaking processes, reflected in public statements, policy documents and media coverage, examine the root causes of abuses and conflict and reflect a better understanding of victims’ needs and grievances

description.narrative: National policymakers were preoccupied with domestic political instability and less approachable for advocacy efforts.

title.narrative: Recipient Region 589: Output III. 1.2 Civil society and victims’ groups increase their capacity and skills to present to international actors (IIIM, CoI and others) information and data in a manner that ties serious human rights abuses including economic and business-related crimes with international law provisions.
Number of victims’ groups from recipient region 589 engaged in designing and leading justice campaigns

description.narrative: SLDP held a webinar in March 2020 for about 20 SNGOs addressing its engagement with non-engaged states focus. SLDP presented the rationale, benefits, and specificities of the identified States. Moreover, SLDP has shared with the participating SNGOs the relevant advocacy profiles/guides and a questionnaire to identify each SNGO thematic interest to consequently identify the relevant States. SLDP also presented their recommendations in this regard.

actual.value: 4 victims groups engaged
SLDP facilitated and accompanied 4 victim’s groups in a meeting with the IIIM in September

SCM (though VDC project) is providing support to CFA in the preparation of 3 individual complaints and 1 report to UN mechanisms. SCM continued its support of enhancing the capacity of CFA's documentation department by utilizing technological advances to develop a software application to help them in accompanying families of the missing and recognition of victims in the Caesar photos

SCM submitted 5 individual complaints to WGEID in its support of CFA. Additionally, SCM continues to provide technical support (including translation) to CFA in communication with WGEID in submitting complaints reporting HR violations.

SLDP supported a families group in drafting and submitting an introductory report to the IIIM addressing their specific and complex issue on enforced disappearance by non-State armed groups. Additionally, SLDP through the HRBU is participating in the Corporate Liability and Sustainable Peace Lab (CLASP Lab) along with other community activists and social justice lawyers from around the world to share experiences and innovate together around the topic of corporate accountability in transitional justice, particularly on how to develop new legal strategies to hold companies accountable for their roles in contributing to, exacerbating, and profiting from conflict.

VDC provided 3 CFA members and employees with training on the basics of international laws (IHL, IHRL, customary laws) VDC\SCM organized a training joined by 2 CFA members on UN special procedures, and SCM keeps providing hands-on coaching to CFA to enable them to file complaints to specific special procedures.

With support of IW, five victims' associations (Taáfi, ADMSP, Massar, CFA, and FFF) launched Truth and justice Charter of their shared vision and demands. This was a combined by a campaign on detention and enforced disapearance led by the five victims' associations. In addition, progress continued on the study of Mechanism to deal with the issue of arbitrary detention and enforced disappearance in Syria. Moreover, IW expanded its partnership and signed contracts with two feminist organaisations: Women Now for development and Urnammu.

title.narrative: Civil society and victims’ groups increase their capacity and skills to present to international actors (IIIM, CoI and others) information and data in a manner that ties serious human rights abuses including economic and business-related crimes with international law provisions

actual.value: With IW support, five victims' associations ( Ta'afi, ADMSP, Massar, CFA, FFF) With support of IW, five victims' associations ( Ta'afi, ADSMP, Massar, CFA, and FFF) launched a study on a Mechanism to address the issue of arbitrary detention and enforced disappearance in Syria. Moreover, IW provided expanded its partnership and signed a contract with small grant with Dawlaty to suport FFF, held a round table meeting to brief key stakeholders (ICRC, ICMP, WGID, OHCHR, CoI, IIIM and UN special Envoy for Syria) on the Mechanism study to adress the issue of arbitrary detention and enforced disappearance in Syria.

title.narrative: Recipient Region 998: Output I.2.1 Method to evaluate victim participation in conflict and post-conflict justice is developed

Developed methodology and indicators for victim participation and satisfaction are considered by relevant government- or civil society actors- to measure progress towards access to justice and SDG 16.3 in conflict and post-conflict settings

description.narrative: The lead researcher hired by IW developed a draft of research framework, which includes an overview of the literature, the questions as well as the proposed case studies. In terms of the methodology, the lead researcher will be using focus groups with survivors and activists and affected communities, supplemented with interviews with policy makers and experts as needed by the research. The country selection for the case studies will be based on the geographical balance, temporal aspect of transitional justice programming, intensity of transitional justice programming and initiatives as well as the participation of youth in transitional justice processes.

actual.value: Due to the Covid related restrictions, there was a slight delay in receiving the first draft of the country studies from the five countries of implementation. IW has received the first draft of the country studies in late June 2021. IW will work on synthetising the findings of these country studies and draft the general report in late Q3. In mid Q2, IW has also added Syria as an additional country study to the research.

The heightened global insecurity as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic has affected progress in various aspect of the project. IW proceeded as cautiously as possible during this period, especially given that our countries of potential research are all based in the Global South. During this period, IW finalised the overarching research framework, shortlisted seven potential case study contexts, and finalised a research agreement for a Tunisian case study. IW reviewed potential research focuses with consultants in Guatemala, Democratic Republic of Congo, Burundi, Tunisia, Indonesia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Colombia. IW also worked to create a new research methodology that would allow us to adapt our research plans to ensure a safe work environment both for all our researchers and their interviewees, who are already vulnerable. IW also signed a consultant agreement with the Tunisian researcher to undertake his research in Q3, should conditions allow.

title.narrative: Recipient Region 998: Output I.1.2 A set of practical guidelines addressed to policymakers and civil society that enables victims’ associations, grassroots organisations to participate effectively in the design and effectiveness of transitional justice measures
Statements of policies adopted at the national, regional or international level include language on victim participation and victim-centred justice

description.narrative: Victim participation was raised in two sessions and one side event at international Access to Justice Conference convened by The Netherlands and the Task Force for Justice in The Hague in February 2019.

title.narrative: Recipient Region 589: Output III.3.1 International policymakers are targeted by advocacy efforts aimed at ensuring that Issues of justice, accountability, and redress are taken into account by those involved in the peace process and activities pertaining to relief and reconstruction.
Public statements and policy developments demonstrate international interest in respecting human rights in business and reconstruction related activities in Syria

description.narrative: Based on HLP expert meeting that took place in July 2019, IW and PAX finalised and published HLP policy brief with recommendation for international actors engaged in Syria.

actual.value: The pandemic has forced a new way of working, therefore, a majority of SCM activities turned into online platforms. SCM launched its report " Mapping The Syrian Media”, a study survey and evaluate 162 media institutions. the study was launched in a webinar with over 100 participants. SCM attends Koplenz trial against 2 ranking officials in the Syrian intelligence, and shared summaries on social media, and detailed reports in Arabic and English. The reports aim to raise awareness on the importance of this first public trial in the Syrian conflict. SCM worked on several activities around 4th Brussels conference on the future of Syria including 2 sessions for Syrian NGOs participating in the conference to coordinate messages, and activities prior to the conference. SCM also conducted a side event on litigation as a gate to transitional justice. The side event in Brussels conference comes as a part of several activities that SCM has been conducting to encourage European countries to allow more space for litigation against war crimes in Syria.

title.narrative: Public statements and policy developments demonstrate support for justice in Syrian negotiations

description.narrative: Victims' groups continued to make advocacy efforts in different areas through publishing reports, participating in advocacy meetings and trainings in order to ensure Justice, accountability and redness are taken into account by International policymaker

actual.value: 3 Syrian and Iraqi civil society groups accessed international policymakers via a side event at the ICC’s annual conference, a public event, a parliamentary visit, advocacy meetings, media appearances, and a conference.

title.narrative: Syrian CSOs and victims’ organisations engaged in justice and accountability work develop strategies and resources to influence peace building processes and reconstruction discussions

actual.value: SCM participated in the 47th session of the UNHRC online side event about the use of torture and the need for accountability to end torture in the Middle East on June 21 2021. The intervention was based on the report written by SCM “Invisible Scars”. On the margin of the HRC 47 regular session and in conjunction with the international day in support of Victims of Torture, the Syrian center for Media and freedom of Expression (SCM) with the support of the Gulf Center for Human Rights (GCHR), held a webinar entitled "Invisible scars: torture in Syria, its legal and socio-economic implications" On the occasion of the World Press Freedom Day SCM published a new report entitled “Syria: The Black Hole for Media work - Ten Years of Violations” that reviews ten years of violations against journalists and media workers who have been targeted with a wide range of violations during the past ten years since 2011.

The first draft of the study on HLP's rights for Palestinian refugees in Syria is done. IW, PAX and number of Syrian organisations coordinated and planned for a webinar in the aim of raising awareness on the urgency and importance of the issue of HLP rights, promoting it on the agenda of the UN, Member States, and the international donor community. The webinar was held in the 4th quarter.

title.narrative: Iraq: Output II. 2.3 Written information and direct policy advice is produced by IW and provided to officials on CSOs and victims’ participation in designing justice and accountability measures
Partner organisations draft policy proposals and statements that are practical and that favour participatory and inclusive justice processes

description.narrative: Written and spoken advice was provided to Dutch diplomats and UNITAD regarding victim and civil society participation in international criminal justice mechanisms.

actual.value: A policy brief was developed with input from civil society partners on the topic of post-ISIS justice and victims’ rights in Iraq and recipient region 589 and distributed to international policymakers.

title.narrative: Tunisia: Output IV. 1.4 Women Committee in the Assembly of Representatives of the People receive technical support through working sessions and ongoing advice on a gender-trans-formative implementation of the final TDC recommendations
Number of legislative or policy reform proposals submitted by CSOs and victims’ organisations.

actual.value: +5 meetings with victim association.

title.narrative: Recipient Region 589: Output III.3.2 Various stakeholders in recipient region 589 reconstruction phase and in business-related activity in are targeted through various activities that aim to highlight the business- related risks and challenges in the region

CSOs and victims’ organisations from recipient region 589 engaged in justice and accountability work develop strategies and resources to influence peace building processes and reconstruction discussions

actual.value: 15 CSOs including a victim association engaged in meeting to discuss Housing Land and Properties rights and reconstruction.

title.narrative: Public statements and policy developments demonstrate international interest in respecting human rights in business and reconstruction related activities in recipient region 589

target.value: SLDP also published a report on documenting business activity impacting human rights in recipient region 589 between April and September 2018. The report highlights patterns of business related human rights violations in the region and is published in both Arabic and English

actual.value: SLDP continues to conduct research to develop dossiers on Syrian financial actors involved in international crimes or conflict related human rights abuses in Syria. During the reporting period, SLDP worked on a number of dossiers, engaged with a number of states and sanctions authorities and responded to different requests from states on sanctions.

title.narrative: Recipient Region 589: Output III. 3.4 Partners working in Syrian context engaged in justice and redress efforts access international policymakers and donors, through bilateral meetings and missions to The Hague, Geneva and New York

Number of business and non-profit organisations involved in reconstruction efforts that demonstrate, publicly or privately, their concern for and commitment to respecting human rights principles in their work in Syria

actual.value: 2 victim groups engaged in justice and redress efforts access international policymakers and donors through bilateral meetings in Netherlands, Germany, Britain and Switzerland.

title.narrative: Recipient Region 589: Output III. 1.1 Policy, technical and legal support is provided to both civil society and victims’ groups, through workshops, tool-kits and hands-on coaching. Topics of capacity building activities may be in areas of transitional justice, UN Human Rights Mechanisms, business and human rights law as well as wider relevant areas of international law
Number of victims’ groups from recipient region 589 engaged in designing and leading justice campaigns

target.value: IW signed contracts with 2 sub-grantees to organise themselves and to advocate for the victim’s voices.

actual.value: 2 victims groups (sub-grantees)

IW provided policy, technical and legal support to 6 Victims' associations. In this regard, the victims ‘associations finalised the final draft of Charter of their shared vision, aims and values. They also started working on advocacy plan to publish it.

title.narrative: Number of CSOs and victims’ groups from recipient region 589 playing an active role in meetings related to international peace building, reconstruction/relief/early recovery and justice debates concerning recipient region 589

actual.value: SCM in cooperation with Durable Solutions Platform (DSP) organized the 3rd "Voices for Refugees" in Geneva- Switzerland, the forum developed the outlines of the advocacy plans for the upcoming year in addition to facilitating and organise meetings for CSOs with representatives from Syria related UN agencies especially the special envoy in addition to UNHCR.

SLDP held 9 trainings and meetings with 7 SNGOs on UN human rights mechanisms which included special focus on legal issues relevant to the SNGOs work and specializations, such as extrajudicial killings, arbitrary detention and enforced disappearance, torture, sexual violence

Women Now for Development finalized the outreach process and opened a call for Syrian women in Syria, Lebanon, and Turkey. 170 applications were received, of which 25 have been chosen to participate in the project.

title.narrative: Recipient Region 589: Output III.3.4 Partners from recipient region 589 engaged in justice and redress efforts, access international policymakers and donors, through bilateral meetings and missions to The Hague, Geneva and New York

CSOs and victims’ organisations from recipient region 589 engaged in justice and accountability work, and develop strategies and resources to influence peace building processes and reconstruction discussions

actual.value: . During the General Assembly of the ICC, SCM participated as panellist in two side events, the first was made in cooperation with IW and PAX about the danger of creating a special ISIS court and the second about cooperation between the IIIM, IIMM and civil society organisations.

3 victim groups engaged in justice and redress efforts through facilitation of access to international policymakers and donors via bilateral meetings in Netherlands, Germany, France, Britain and swiss.

ADMSP had two online bilateral meetings with COI and IIIM. Ta'afi participated in online event with WGEID in the line of 45th session of HRC. CFA participated in online event with WGEID, in line of the 45th session of HRC.

SCM participated in a panel discussion at Humanity House during an event organised by Impunity Watch; about ISIS combatants and presented their views in a meeting with the Dutch parliament on the same subject.
SCM participated in an even at Humanity House in The Hague; on the topic of refugees return.

title.narrative: Recipient region 998: Output I. 1.3 UN agencies/programmes and diplomats of 3 to 4 states are targeted by advocacy engagements ( e.g. meetings, events, distribution of publications and material), both at the regional and international levels, that promote content of output developed in I. 1.1 and I. 1.2
Statements of policies adopted at the national, regional or international level include language on victim participation and victim-centred justice

actual.value: Final report of Transitional Justice Working Group of Task Force for Justice includes substantial language on victim participation.
Once all the materials from output 1.1 and 1.2 are finalized, IW is planning for an advocacy campaign in late Q3 to promote the findings and the recommendations of the research

title.narrative: Tunisia: Output IV. 1.1 Research and analysis are produced to assess the work and the final report of the Truth and Dignity Commission (TDC) and their finding are published and distributed through workshops
Number of victims’ groups consulted by officials and participating through their representatives in public debate around the implementation of TDC recommendations

actual.value: IW launched expert assessment of recommendations of TDC
IW organised retreat with three partners to assess the final report of Truth and Dignity Commission

title.narrative: Iraq: Output II.2.1 A functioning civil society platform is created and its capacity is developed through trainings/workshops
Partner organisations draft policy proposals and statements that are practical and that favour participatory and inclusive justice processes

actual.value: IW supported a group of activists threatened with murder to write and distribute an urgent appeal for international solidarity to policymakers. IW also assisted an Iraqi partner to secure funds for urgent protection and temporary relocation of threatened human rights defenders. In collaboration with 11 Iraqi NGOs and PAX, a policy brief calling for accountability for violations against Iraqi civil activists was developed and distributed to Iraqi and international policymakers.

title.narrative: Recipient Region 998: Output I. 3.2 An effective global network of victims is established and understands the potential to advance their rights and interests through the SDGs agenda
10 to 12 victim organisations representing Africa, the Americas, Asia, Europe and MENA initiate the formation of a functioning global victim network

actual.value: In Q1, IW has worked with INOVAS Core group members to develop the content for the network's website to be able to launch it. In, Q2 IW will register the network in the Netherlands and will launch the network in late Q2. IW is working closely with the members to develop pilot projects that INOVAS can implement in Q3/Q4

In Q2, IW has continued working with INOVAS Core group members to develop the content for the network's website to be able to launch it. The Core group members have formed different committees to be able to work themselves on the launching of the network, as well as developing an advocacy plan and peer-to-peer exchange activities that the network can implement in Q3/Q4. The members are aiming to launch the network in early Q4 once all the materials required are finalized. The registration of the network in The Hague is still in process and should be finalized in early Q3.

title.narrative: Recipient Region 998: Output I.3.3 Three to 4 Governments, UN, EU, AU and OAS policymakers are targeted by advocacy activities conducted by the global network and which aims to ensure inclusion of victims’ perspectives in implementation of SDG 16.3 and access to justice plans
Statements and activities of global victims’ network demonstrate that it is actively advocating for their rights in the framework of global efforts to advance SDG 16+ and 2030 agenda.

actual.value: In preparation for the launch of the network, IW has been working with the core group members to develop an advocacy strategy for the network to reach out to the international community to ensure the inclusion of the victims' perspective in the implementation of SDG 16.3

title.narrative: Recipient Region 589: Output III. 2.2 New documentation methodology and tools with set standards of security, confidentiality and reliability are developed and applied
Material produced by international stakeholders and policymakers involved in justice efforts refer to documentation and material produced by SCM.

actual.value: SCM contributed to the preparation of reports submitted to the Human Rights Council at the September 2019 session.

title.narrative: Recipient Region 589: Output III. 1.1 Policy, technical and legal support is provided to both civil society and victims’ groups, through workshops, toolkits and hands-on coaching. Topics of capacity building activities may be in areas of transitional justice, UN Human Rights Mechanisms, business and human rights law as well as wider relevant areas of international law

Through public statements, strategy discussions and other means CSOs and victims’ groups demonstrate increased knowledge in areas such as peacebuilding, documentation and memorialisation, victims’ rights and participation, TJ approaches, HLP, and business and human rights

description.narrative: SCM published on its digitals, a series of recommendation targeting civil society actors, human rights defenders, citizen journalists, on their cyber security

actual.value: IW provided ongoing technical and legal support to 6 Victims groups while working on joint advocacy strategy for advancing victim's rights including a Charter of shared vision, aims and values. In addition, IW provided policy, legal and technical support for 5 victims groups to work strategic vision on how to address the detention and enforced disappearance issue.
