IW provided policy, technical and legal support to 6 Victims' associations. In this regard, the victims ‘associations finalised the final draft of Charter of their shared vision, aims and values. They also started working on advocacy plan to publish it.

SCM participated in proofreading, translation and design of a report conducted in collaboration with CFA and Swiss peace on the rights of families of missing persons. SCM continues to provide CFA with IT support through hand-on coaching and personal training session, in addition to back-end support for CFA’s website in relation to security and content update. SCM provided consultation to CFA in the preparation of their strategic plans and continues providing financial support in reporting and budgeting.

Support continued to victims’ associations in their advocacy plan to launch “Truth and Justice Charter”. In this regard, IW contracted with Advocacy consultant to help the victims’ associations to develop and implement their advocacy plan around the Charter. In addition, progress continued on the study of Mechanism to deal with the issue of arbitrary detention and enforced disappearance in Syria.

Women Now for Development finalized the outreach process and opened a call for Syrian women in Syria, Lebanon, and Turkey. 170 applications were received, of which 25 have been chosen to participate in the project.

title.narrative: Number of CSO and victims’ groups (from recipient region 589) engaged in designing and leading justice campaigns

actual.value: 5 victims and families led groups took part in 2 introduction meetings with personnel from the UN Human Rights Special Rapporteurs.

IW provided policy, technical and legal support to 6 Victims' associations. In this regard, the victims ‘associations finalised the final draft of Charter of their shared vision, aims and values. They also started working on advocacy plan to publish it.
One Victims' group received hands-on coaching in the field of IT, as well as on coordinating and monitoring projects and event.

title.narrative: Number of sessions on technical and legal support around the special procedures of the UN Human Rights mechanisms

actual.value: SCM organized and conducted more than 20 consultation and preparatory meetings with Civil Societies organizations and Victims and Families’ groups between the end of August and early September to support and push for policy recommendations on issues that affect their work.

title.narrative: Iraq: Output II.1.3 Local civil society groups, especially victims’ groups have access to international policymakers through missions, advocacy tours and side events

8 to 10 CSOs and victims’ groups demonstrate - in their programmes and publications - increased understanding of their rights, the nature of the crimes they experienced, the recourse that transitional justice approaches offer and of their potential as a political force that can influence justice policies.

actual.value: Syrian and Iraqi civil society groups accessed international policymakers via a side event at the ICC’s annual conference, a public event, a parliamentary visit, advocacy meetings, media appearances, and a conference. Case studies of civil society responses to unlawful killings of protestors in other countries relevant to the Iraqi context were developed and shared with approximately 8 civil society organisations to facilitate learning from others’ experiences and develop knowledge about how they can serve a broader transitional justice agenda.

title.narrative: Recipient Region 589: Output III. 2.3 Strategic litigation efforts of SCM and other organisation or bodies (e.g. IIIM) are supported through the provision of relevant available data
Court material shows use of documentation and data collected by SCM

actual.value: - The VDC's database helped SCM's Strategic litigation project –SLP- respond to 5 requests from war crimes units (3 in Netherlands and 2 in France) for investigations into war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Syria. -SCM has testified against a former leader in Ahrar Al-Sham, who is arrested by the Dutch Police on charges of committing crimes in Sahl al-Ghab (the Al-Ghab Plain region) in 2015 in the battle of Al-Nasr (Battle of Victory) and during the liberation of Sahl al-Ghab. SCM reviewed the files that included the investigation carried out by its team and shared them with the Dutch National Police Force (the War Crime Unit) to establish a coordination regarding the witness and resource program on Ahrar al-Sham. This testimony played a pivotal role in uncovering the horrendous acts and violations committed by the armed group. - SCM filed 4 complaints at the Dutch National Force (The War Crime Unit) regarding suspect fighters with the Syrian government forces and their allies and facilitated communication with witnesses and victims. -SCM Filed a complaint in Netherlands against an ISIS leader. -SCM responded to requests by the war crimes unites regarding the violations committed in Al-Raqqa by Ahrar al-Sham, and Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham."

The database helped SCM's Strategic litigation project "SLP" respond to 4 requests from war crimes units (2 in Netherlands and 2 in France) for investigations into war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Syria. SCM (through VDC) provided COI-Syria with contact information of witnesses, data and documentation to be used in their coming report

Dozens of missing persons have been identified, in addition to the arrest in the Netherlands of members of Islamic militant groups who fought in recipient region 589 and committed abuses amounting to war crimes and crimes against humanity.
The SCM database helped the Center's litigation team respond to 27 requests for investigations into war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in recipient region 589.
The SCM documentation and database also contributed to a remarkable development in the progress of the investigation (in France) of 3 special cases against war crimes and crimes against humanity.

The VDC's database helps SCM's Strategic litigation project "SLP" respond to 10 requests from war crimes units in a number of European countries for investigations into war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Syria.

title.narrative: Iraq: Output II.3.1Research is produced on victims’ needs and demands and findings disseminated to policymakers

Policymaking processes, reflected in public statements, policy documents and media coverage, examine the root causes of abuses and conflict and reflect a better understanding of victims’ needs and grievances

actual.value: Work commenced on a piece of research on violent norms of masculinity and the militarisation of Iraqi society as a root cause of women’s disempowerment. Iraqi and international policymakers were targeted via the policy brief mentioned above. IW co-organised a briefing between Iraqi and international NGOs to coordinate advocacy on redress and accountability in light of the anniversary of the Iraqi protest movement. IW provided technical support and advice to UNITAD and to a group of Iraqi NGOs to express their ambitions for partnership with UNITAD in a joint communication.

title.narrative: Iraq: II.3.5 UNITAD explores ways to improve victims’ participation and examine options to help address abuses and grievances that fall outside of its mandate through confidential engagement and advice sharing

Policymaking processes, reflected in public statements, policy documents and media coverage, examine the root causes of abuses and conflict and reflect a better understanding of victims’ needs and grievances

actual.value: Written and spoken advice was provided to UNITAD regarding victim and civil society participation in international criminal justice mechanisms
